importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The population decline from 2010 to 2020 reached about 25%, marking a critical period in the decline of the North Atlantic right whale population.
A pair of North Atlantic right whales were observed interacting at Cape Cod Bay, highlighting the species' presence in key migratory and feeding areas.
A North Atlantic right whale was photographed off New England, indicating ongoing monitoring and presence in critical habitats.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The past decade saw a 25% population decline due to ship collisions and entanglement in fishing gear, setting the stage for conservation efforts.
Over the last four years, the population has shown slow but positive growth, with an estimated 384 individuals in 2025, up from 376 in 2024.

keyTakeAways: The North Atlantic right whale population has increased to an estimated 384 individuals in 2025, up from 376 in 2024, marking a positive trend after a 25% decline between 2010 and 2020.
This recovery is attributed to sustained conservation efforts, including new management measures in Canada and improved protection in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.
Despite progress, the population remains vulnerable due to threats such as ship strikes and fishing gear entanglements.
Recent data shows that four mother whales gave birth to calves, and some have shorter reproductive intervals, indicating improved reproductive health.
Only 11 calves were born in the most recent year, below researchers' hopes, but the entry of new females into the reproductive pool is a positive sign.
Scientists remain cautiously optimistic due to a lack of mortalities and fewer injuries compared to previous years, though the population is still on the brink of extinction.
Environmental groups emphasize the need for stronger legal protections, warning that weakening the Marine Mammal Protection Act and NOAA’s science-based safeguards would endanger recovery efforts.

namedEntities.name: North Atlantic right whale

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The North Atlantic right whale is the focus of the article, with its population growth and conservation status central to the narrative.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The North Atlantic right whale population has shown a positive trend, increasing to an estimated 384 individuals in 2025 after a 25% decline from 2010 to 2020. Scientists attribute this recovery to improved conservation measures, including new management in Canada and reduced whale injuries and mortalities. Despite progress, threats such as ship strikes and fishing gear entanglements persist. Encouragingly, four mother whales produced calves this year, with shorter reproductive intervals observed, indicating improved reproductive health. However, only 11 calves were born, and experts remain cautiously optimistic, warning that continued threats and potential weakening of legal protections could jeopardize the species’ long-term survival.
title: North Atlantic Right Whale Population Shows Positive Growth Amid Conservation Efforts
